Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Heat-Induced Polymer Bonding of Coarse Aggregates

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Plastic-bonded soils may be a sustainable method to construct more durable roadways, render soils with higher bearing capacity and liquefaction resistance, develop better waste isolation and soil retention systems, and build upon environments where conventional cements yield poor performance. This research will investigate the extent to which the strength and stiffness of a soil may be improved for applications such as these using a technique that glues the soil grains with recyclable, durable, and acid-resistant plastic. This research will study the engineering behavior of coarse aggregates fused together with polymer fines that are heated to bond the particles to make the soil mass stiffer and stronger.

Cementation-based soil stabilization techniques typically involve the use of mineral cementing agents (e.g., calcium-based). Although strong, these agents are brittle and soluble in acidic environments. Furthermore, re-cementation of de-cemented aggregates remains a challenge. The objective of this research is to explore the feasibility of a novel cementation method that uses recycled polymers and heat injection. Heat causes polymer particles in a soil mixture to soften and coalesce at the grain contacts. The polymer solidifies upon cooling, yielding a cemented soil. The result is inter-particle bonds that are non-brittle and chemically stable under a wide range of relevant environmental conditions. Moreover, re-cementation can be readily implemented by reheating de-cemented grains. The research activities will include the following scope: (1) characterize the improvement of and/or alterations in soil strength, stiffness, hydraulic conductivity, water retention, and creep behavior attained by polymeric bonding, (2) gain understanding of the role of soil and mixture properties (such as mineral composition and polymer content) on the alterations of the engineering properties, and (3) assess strength and stiffness recovery attained by reheating debonded soil (i.e., healing). Laboratory experiments conducted with custom-made and standard geotechnical testing apparatus modified with acoustic emission monitoring systems will be used to implement the research, and scanning electron microscopy will be used for micro-characterization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Turning soil into rock would be ideal for most civil engineering applications. This is because rock is stiffer and stronger than soil, and also more resistant to earthquake action and to cyclic loads (such as the forces imposed by vehicles as they pass over a roadway). The earth can easily turn soil into rock, simply by melting the soil and allowing the resulting magma to cool. Such process requires enormous amounts of energy, and therefore, man?made rock?making of this sort remains unfeasible. An alternative is to bond the grains together. This award funded a comprehensive study associated with the development of a novel technology by which soil is feasibly turned into rock. First, the soil is mixed with polymeric, i.e., plastic, powder. The mix is then heated: the plastic melts into menisci located at particle contacts, solidifies upon cooling, and renders the soil cemented. That is, the resulting rock is an agglomerate of heat-glued soil grains, i.e., a polymer bonded soil (PBS). Pictures are shown in Figure 1.

Specifically, this award funded research to characterize improvements in the engineering properties of coarse soils attained by polymer-bonding via heat treatment, and to develop an understanding of the underlying mechanics that give rise to such improvements. We found that the strength of PBS results from a competition amongst the strengths of the polymer, the mineral that makes the grains, and the bond shared by the polymer and the grain surfaces (adhesion). For example, the polymer polyethylene and its adhesion to calcite grains are both stronger than calcite, so the strength of calcite PBS is dominated by the strength of calcite. We also found that the strength of PBS is dependent on the polymer type and content, the grains’ roughness and range of sizes, and the presence of water, particularly if the soil contains clay. By making comparisons, we found PBS to be significantly stronger than sands cemented with other agents (such as Portland cement and bio-induced calcium carbonate). Furthermore, we were able to prove that some of the initial strength of PBS can be effectively recovered by healing, i.e., by reheating and thus re-softening the polymer in a fractured PBS. From a sustainability standpoint, PBS emerges as a strong competitor, particularly when the polymer is recovered from waste plastics and/or when solar radiation is used to impose the heat treatment (as proven via experiments conducted). The latter offers an attractive possibility for extraterrestrial construction.
